title: Technology Parks and Technology Transfer - Making Full Use of Cross-Border Opportunities
segmentation: Welcome to my presentation about technology, parks and technology transfer.

Making the full use out of it, which is a little bit strange for me because I'm not the manager of the technology park, but I'm the manager of a small company which is related to the University to the management of the park and we are responsible for technology transfer and for visibility for the companies and especially the University.
I will explain you more in detail.
When you look at the Austrians technology, innovation and startup centers that press and 110 technology innovation and startup centers and seven of them are in Carinthia.
Green chairs 2.3% R&D rate.
It's a third place in Austria which is quite well for us, but it's also you have to look where you start from because there was not much done in the past.
And then if you grow then you have a intense rate, but we want to try to keep this rate and keep it increasing and international ranking its own position.
29 and it was a study made on 208 regions in Europe.
But to show you how it worked in Carinthia, how it started to set up, I want to show you how the region looked like in the 90s.
You don't have to read everything or understand the names in it, but it just shows you there were a few technology related companies which were like leaked companies.
Some small industry parks and Innovation Center.
If we look at.
Development what happened still until from the 90s until now?
You can see that a lot happened there a lot more technology based research centers like the CTR.

You have foundation center which is called build who helps to to get spinoff surrounding to get inventors being a real intrapreneur and getting the company running the leaks and science and Technology Park was found and also lakeside lap scheme behind.
Which is our company which was last year?
And now what are we doing now?

Corinthian now is planning not only to have this structure all over Carinthia, but to make clusters because we understood the most important thing is to get visibility and to show that you have some strength in some of the parts which would be, for example, information technology or down.
Here sustainable technologies like solar like renewable energy or.
Electronic and megatronic
And then you can see the lakeside science and Technology Park in Lakeside Labs is very close to the University and the University of Applied Science in Villa.
The park itself.
It's targeted well close to the University to work with them, but has an orientation on research and development.
Also education, which is very good because you're close to the University and you have all the people over there production.
And services.
It's owned 1/3 by the Republic of Austria 1/3 of Carinthia and Bonser of Klagenfurt off the CD itself.
We chose that the city is also interested to have it and to keep it running.
We have about 8 buildings now with 600 jobs, 24 companies like us in AC like Infineon.
And it's planned, and they're already building, starting to build their ten buildings and up to 2000 potential jobs in this park.
Only in this park.
And it focuses.
And that was very important for us to be specialized.
Focuses on ICT on telematics and traffic, telematics and self organized network systems.
That's where we come in.
Place them the utilization of the park is already 86%.

That's why the state and the land of Carinthia said, OK, let's expand the park now because it's important and they have already a lot of companies they are interested to get into the park because they understand that it's important to be in there.

To get the visibility that we make a lot of exchange already, not as we would wish that it works, but we're already doing it and the management of the park is doing a really good job with that because they're doing things that you would think.
OK, it's very trivial.
It's very normal, but they make like an informal breakfast.

Once a month and every company that comes new into the park can introduce itself to the others and you're sitting there in a very nice atmosphere and you're just talking to each other and to get to know each other.
And we have one event which is also very nice, is walking together and we're making a walk somewhere.
Last time we did it in Slovenia in the cost.
The other time it was in Italy in Valencia.
And it gives the possibility far away from your office.
Hopefully without any mobile phone, but then talking to each other and finding sometimes ideas on how you can collaborate on how you can work together.
And I think there is what it starts.
That's why I'm talking about that.

You need to start to get strength inside here in your own country and then think cross border because if you expand too fast if you want to do everything at once then it's like a bubble and it will burst.
Well now, Lakeside Labs was invented in 2008 in February.
And we are now something like the link between the companies in the park, but not only in the park.
Also in the region and the University.
The background is that about 3 four years ago, some knew.
Information communication technology institutes were founded at the University.
the Korean government help with it CVF, but they figured out very easy, very quick.
Well, it doesn't only help to get professors over there and try to attract students, but especially in the field of ICT.
You need people who can work in projects because you will not attract good researchers if you don't have good projects to work with.
So what we're doing is we're working in close cooperation and we have possibilities to get funds for self organized network systems.
That's our specialization.
And we want to make the University these technologies institutions visible, but also, and that's the multiple effect the park and Carinthia, and suddenly it appears on the landscape.
And we found out last year we were on the IF source, which is a very good conference for self organized network systems that people were saying, Oh yeah, you are from Lakeside Labs.
I know that and what are you doing and they wanted to know more about us and more about the University and Institute.
So what are we doing in technology transfer?
Well, there are different levels and I would say there are different fields we are working in.

And together with universities and I wrote not only University of Klagenfurt, but also we are working now in an interactive project together with the universities in fully innovative free illuminator Julia with food in a mysterious and also with some of the universities in Germany.
And we're trying to get the scientific exchange, know how exchange and it's very important and what we did here is on the basis of self organized network systems we are.
Providing a week which we call research days and researchers from all over the world, and I really mean all over the world where people from US from.
Germany from don't remember they have so many.
It makes it call and they come and they are willing to discuss about this issue and find new possibilities, new ways and.
Following up from this, we have new projects.
We have new ideas.
We have new ways to address things because we get no help from outside and it's also one thing we do.
We invite professors from all over the world to come, which are specialists within self organized network systems to give speeches to stay for about two or three months.
Most of the time they just have time for one month and to teach our students also all these things.
But also ask him to work within projects to help us and give us some hints on project.
For some problems that we have.

In research, we have some research centers in Carinthia, but also outside guarantee that we're working close together and we're working on projects with them and companies we're working together with Infineon Asthenic caps on projects and we're still looking for in the office Adriatic region to get regional economic effects through this.
That's just a small list of the universities in the companies we work.
With.
And then I thought, OK, um, when you're sitting in here, you probably want to know?
OK, what did we learn out of it?
What was the challenges that we had to face, and what would I recommend when you do that?
And while you should try to seek industry, cooperation is the same thing as we do, like not only staying here, getting the strength 1st at home, but then getting outside.
Take part in cross border projects because there are some funding possibilities that you have up there.
What we're doing is we do international recruiting because we get diverse minds in inside diverse knowledge that was taught in different universities.
So we try to get researchers from all over the world and we're supporting very much the exchange of know how, because we think that's the basis for everything.
But you have to be open in the cross border relationship because you face a lot of different mentalities.
You have a language barrier.
There's different cultures and it's why it's getting sometimes very difficult.
And even if you interact project, you have some companies with you at the first time.
They're saying, like I'm not sure about it.
Plus the application is very difficult, but that's what we're doing.
We're doing the application for them so that this first hurdle.
It's taken and then ask them and help them to get over the obstacles that they see within a cross border cooperation.
And there is another interact project that we're right now in.
We are in the application phase together with Slovenia and it's gonna be also an ICT.
But more on what kind of process is and what kind of background do you need to get a good cooperation?
And how can you strengthen companies also afterwards after they did the project with us to get into good cooperation, which are the do's and don'ts when you when you set up such a international or?
Cross regional project.

And well, what we also think it's very, very important that the government government supports it and you have the right social environment for the people working with you and what we also found out that.
Lawson regulations are some sometimes an obstacle that's also one thing that we want to address with this Slovenian project.
And well, I would just recommend try first to get the strength within your country within your park within your company.
Then go outside and don't don't have all these obstacles or if you have obstacles, try to overcome them.
Be open.

I'm not saying be blindfolded and go with everybody because I know there are a lot of bad examples also for across for the corporations, but it doesn't mean if you do a cross border cooperation that everybody wants just to take.
You know how that everybody just wants to take your Ipr's.
It's also if you put them together, 1 + 1 is really three, it can be 3 and you can make it thank you.
Thank you very much.
Miss Burger for presenting your experience as a science, technology and innovation park and really very much convinced that Carinthia can play a very positive role.
It has great potential for this Corporation with central and southeastern European countries and are there any questions?
Let's play.
Turn to your through your presentation.
The old editor.
What do you mean by that, just?
I.
So.
Initiate country skills today at the Arctic and into Alpine region.
No, I I don't think so.
I mean, there are a lot of new initiatives, but I'm not aware of the name by itself, so I'm not sure if it's still the way.
Mention.
I know it is still existing but not very animation office at.
But it's politically not really relevant anymore because it's true independence of Slovenia and Croatia.
The levels have changed and doesn't fit that weather together anymore.
Do you also take care about universities, peoples?
Yes.

I mean one of our targets that we have within the game behind is that we gonna create spinoffs and we're working together with the built with the Foundation Cooper Company within the Lakeside Park, which is very nice also because they're very close to us and we can exchange the know how.
But yes, that's definitely one of our targets that we have and we are also helping them to get on the feeds.

Well, the lakeside lab scheme has now found that one year ago, so usually you would say OK, one of the spinners would come out of one of the projects that you have, and there are some of the researchers to say, OK, they could imagine to become entrepreneur afterwards with the idea they have.
But because they're just running for one year now and they're meant to be for three years, it's not really clear if afterwards you will say OK, but I think after about two years.
It's really time to look after the market.
Is the idea really debt ripe to go into the market and then look and get them together with built that they get real good spin off?
We're going to help them as well.
Population.
Yes.
Were there a lot will not spin offs from the well.
You could not really say spinoffs.
I mean there are a lot of ex students from the University of Klagenfurt who are already entrepreneurs within the build center and they're already, I think 8 or 10 companies established over there.
They provide them with an office for about 2 years.
They have all the infrastructure.
They get some support.
For example, if you need measurement equipment or testing equipment, you can have it for free.
From the Applied University of Applied Science or also at the University of Klagenfurt.
So they really helped support him.
And the good thing is, and I think that's one of the biggest advantages to help you with the business case.
They help you with some good courses in how you do business, how you can, uh, what's the obstacles that you could have?
What are the main failure points that companies could make that they fail in the first one or two years?
So that's something really.
Good and interesting to follow.
Any further questions?
Well and thank you again.
